awd_abstract_narration:
This RAPID award will support an intensive international multi-disciplinary effort to salvage critical organic remains from rapidly degrading cultural deposits at the unique site of Gardar E47 at modern Igaliku in the former Norse Eastern Settlement in Greenland.   This site is unique in that it represents a church and manor farm from the 11th century, was the administrative and religious center for the first settlement of the Norse in Greenland, and remained thus until the extinction of the Norse ca 1450.   As such, the Gardar site has the potential to provide unique insights into the changing structure and organization of Norse Greenland and its society response to climate change and culture contact at this time period.   

The site at Gardar is very rich in archaeofauna, which is the source of concern and the reason for this RAPID proposal.   When Gardar was assessed as part of an IPY project on how climate change was affecting cultural resources in the Arctic, it was highlighted as a highly endangered site.  As recently as 1981 the site was shown to have great preservation of organic materials; unfortunately, the previously favorable conditions are rapidly changing due to changing climate conditions in the Arctic.  The decrease in frozen ground is creating an unidentifiable ?bone mush? out of much of the previously well preserved organic materials at the site.  In addition to the changing environmental conditions, the local farmers have been cutting deep drainage ditches into the meadows surrounding the site in order to drain off the now standing water. These ditches have further destabilized the site exposing it to further melting and destruction of organic data.  The site has been nominated by the Government of Greenland as a UN World Heritage Site because of its unique contribution to the cultural history of modern Greenland, making the threatened data and the scientific analyses and insights that could be gained all the more important.  

The field team has three objectives for the 2012 season: to 1) carry out an intensive season of rescue excavation and site documentation of the most endangered deposits; 2) ensure effective post-excavation curation and analysis of the rescued materials; and 3) leave the Nunatta Katersugaasivia Allagaaterqarfial/The Greenland National Museum & Archives (NKA) with an accurate digital site map and geophysical prospection results they will need to effectively manage this nominated World heritage site for the benefit o f the Greenlandic community.

por.por_cntn:
The site of Gardar (modern Igaliku) in SW Greenland represents one of the most important Norse archaeological sites in Greenland. It was a major farm from first settlement ca. 985 AD and in 1127 became the episcopal seat of the Bishops of Greenland. Down to the abandonment of the settlement ca. 1450 Gardar was the largest farm complex in  Norse Greenland, and had a stone cathedral, bishop’s manor, and impressive stock buildings capable of holding up to 100 head of cattle (the average farmer probably had 4-8 cows). This large manorial holding shows evidence of soil augmentation and small scale irrigation and the still productive wet meadows around the visible ruins are probably still the result of Norse land management.  In 2005 a UK science team led by Kevin Edwards and Paul Buckland noted bone and wooden artifacts emerging from a newly dug drainage ditch in the wet meadow and two AMS radiocarbon dates spanning the Norse occupation were obtained.  Follow up work by the Greenland National Museum and Archives and the North Atlantic Biocultural Organization teams during the IPY indicated that there were extensive organic-rich deposits remaining, and that the modern drainage combined with rapid soil warming due to modern climate change was rapidly degrading these well preserved materials.  The NABO cooperative teams (from Greenland Museum and Archives, Danish National Museum, CUNY, Archaeological Institute Iceland, Stirling University, University of Iceland) mounted an emergency response in the summer of 2012, funded in large part by this NSF RAPID award (1119354). 

  The rescue project opened two areas (area A 10 x 8 m, area B 7 x 5 m) for open area stratigraphic excavation, carried out a systematic coring survey and sampling of exposed cuts, collected large organic samples, collected material for 14 AMS C14 dates, and produced a high resolution digital map of the site. Finds included over 5,500 pieces of worked wood, 2,000 wooden artifacts (including carved furniture, wooden toys and 7 runic inscriptions) , 450 steatite (soapstone) objects, medieval pottery (exceptionally rare in Greenland), several leather finds including a portion of a decorated leather belt, two lead weights, part of a quern stone and a baking plate made of Norwegian schist (almost unique in bread-poor Greenland but common find in Shetland, Orkney and Norway). The organic samples included over 5,000 identifiable animal bones including the full range of imported domestic mammals (pig, cattle, sheep, goat, horse, dog) as well as walrus, polar bear, whale, and large numbers of seal bones (as  usual dominated by the migratory harp seal). The bone-rich layers could be placed in two phases ca. 1155-1266 and c 1270-1389 calibrated AD, and provide proxy evidence for the Norse reaction to the sudden climate cooling of c. 1275-1300.  The Gardar archaeofauna is unusual in that it does not show the marked increase in seal bones after c. 1300  visible in most of the other stratified Greenlandic archaeofauna,  and like other higher status sites it also maintains a high ratio of cattle to sheep and goat bones. The Gardar archaeofauna also has more caribou bone than any other Eastern Settlement site, probably also reflecting elite status. Charred and uncharred plant material was recovered from both on site flotation and whole soil samples, including substantial amounts of barley (almost certainly an import) and a single hazel nut shell that generated an AMS 2 sigma calibrated date of 995-1153 AD. This nut shell could possibly be North American (the Vinland voyages were ca. 1000 and sporadic contact continued after) but may more probably be European. Ancient DNA analysis is underway on sea mammal bones and domestic dogs, and preliminary results indicate a possible inter-breeding of European (Norse) and North American (Inuit?) dogs at some point.  ...
